Spokespeople at the PBOC, China’s Commerce Ministry and China’s cabinet, the State Council, didn’t respond to requests to comment. The move to devalue the yuan comes as China’s leaders are fighting a host of economic ills that could endanger their goal of achieving a 7% annual growth target for this year, which would be the lowest in a quarter century. They include weak factory output, slumping demand from both home and abroad, and persistent risks of falling prices that could make it harder for Chinese companies to pay off debt.

Now, China has done a U-turn. On Tuesday it pushed the yuan into the largest devaluation in its history, cutting its value against the dollar by 1.9%. The move roiled financial markets and set off worries that other central banks would follow suit.
